title: 115_hr3301
content: The Act may be cited as the "Compensating Legacy Artists for their Songs, Service, and Important Contributions to Society Act" or the "CLASSICS Act." It amends Title 17, United States Code, by adding a new chapter on unauthorized digital performance of pre-1972 sound recordings. The "CLASSICS Act" addresses unauthorized digital performance of pre-1972 sound recordings. It states that performing such recordings without consent before February 15, 2067, will be subject to copyright infringement remedies. Transmissions of these recordings will be considered authorized if made by a transmitting entity publicly performing them through digital audio transmissions. The "CLASSICS Act" allows for authorized digital performance of pre-1972 sound recordings through digital audio transmissions subject to statutory licensing requirements. Transmitting entities must pay statutory royalties and provide notice of their use of the sound recordings to comply with regulations. The "CLASSICS Act" allows for authorized digital performance of pre-1972 sound recordings through statutory licensing. Transmissions of sound recordings fixed before February 15, 1972, are considered authorized if included in a voluntary license agreement between the rights owner and the performing entity. Royalties must be paid for these transmissions, with 50 percent going to performance royalties for qualifying recordings. The "CLASSICS Act" mandates the distribution of performance royalties for transmissions under the license to a designated collective, in accordance with specific guidelines. These royalties are the sole payments entitled to featured and nonfeatured artists for such transmissions. This section does not prevent other licenses from directing additional royalties to the collective for distribution. The "CLASSICS Act" mandates the distribution of performance royalties for transmissions to a designated collective, following specific guidelines. This section does not limit any rights or remedies under state law for sound recordings fixed before February 15, 1972, except for preempting certain common law copyright claims related to digital audio transmissions. This section preempts common law copyright claims for sound recordings fixed before February 15, 1972, related to digital audio transmissions. The section requires that reproductions meet statutory licensing requirements or be exempt, pay royalties, and provide notice within 270 days. The section outlines the requirements for sound recordings protected under copyright law for digital audio transmissions and reproductions. It includes rules for common law copyright claims and public performance rights. The section clarifies that public performance rights in sound recordings are not affected by this law. It also limits remedies for unauthorized performance of sound recordings fixed before February 15, 1972, under subsection (a). The section clarifies that public performance rights in sound recordings are not affected by this law and limits remedies for unauthorized performance of sound recordings fixed before February 15, 1972. Principles of equity apply to remedies for violations of this section, and it is considered 'intellectual property laws' under section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934. The term 'rights owner' refers to the person with the exclusive right to reproduce a sound recording under state law. Title 17, United States Code, is amended by adding a new chapter at the end.
